title-group.article-title: Le deuil d'Électre en terre américaine

abstract.p: America has known, over the years, a number of « Electras », more or less innovative, or faithful to the Greek model. When he wrote his own version, Mourning Becomes Electra, in 1931, Eugene O'Neill wanted to write « a modern psychological play, fate springing out of the family ». In spite of some melodramatic elements, of the predominance of « gloom » over « doom », and of « sorrow » over « mourning », and even though « genes » can't replace « genos », there are moments in which the rebellion, the « splendid failure » of two strong women transcends the anecdote and achieves tragic beauty.
